intro: Isoplexis canariensis var. tomentosa, commonly known as the Canary Island mistflower, is a flowering plant native to the Canary Islands. It is a member of the Loganiaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or coastal areas, thriving in well-drained soils. Its flowers are often pink or purple and bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and vulnerable species.
